document.masterDocTitle: Contribution to the knowledge of Cloeodes Traver 1938 (Ephemeroptera, Baetidae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Contribution to the knowledge of Cloeodes Traver 1938 (Ephemeroptera, Baetidae)

subSubSection.paragraph:
“Genus nr.
Neocloeon
”: Roback 1966 : 133, Pl. 3: Figs 37–40 (larva).

Etymology. The adjective
nigrohumeris
refers to pair of black lines on anterolateral parts of imaginal mesonotum (“shoulders”).

Material examined.
Holotype : L-S-I ♂ {specimen [XIX](3)2013}, PERU , Region Loreto , Provincia Ucayali , Pampa Hermosa , Quebrada Huanganaico , 7°12'S , 75°22'W ,
18.VIII.2013
, coll. N. Kluge & L. Sheyko
.
Paratypes : the same locality and collectors,
18–20.VIII.2013
: 5 L-S-I ♂ , 1 L-S ♂ , 9 L-S-I ♀ , 3 L-S ♀ , 3 L/S ♂ , 2 L/S ♀ , 1 larva. Provincia Ucayali ,
17 km NNE Contamana
, Aguas Termales , 7°11'S , 74°57'W ,
26.VII–4.VIII.2013
, coll. N. Kluge & L. Sheyko : 3 L-S-I ♂ , 1 L-S/I ♂ , 2 L-S-I ♀ , 1 L-S ♀ , 3 L/S ♂ , 1 L/S ♀ , 7 larvae
.
Provincia Maynas ,
Quebrada El Sabalo
(right tributary of Rio Itaya ) between Puente Itaya ( 57 km from Iquitos ) and San Joaquin (at Rio Amazon ), 4°16'S , 73°27'W ,
1–16.II.2006
, coll. N. Kluge : 1 L-S-I ♂ , 7 L/S ♂ , 5 L/S ♀ , 33 larvae
.

Descriptions. Larva .
CUTICULAR COLORATION: Cuticle partly colorless, partly light brownish. Most part of head colorless. Pronotum and/or mesonotum either with colorless, light brownish and darker brow areas ( Figs 94 , 103 ), or at most part colorless with few small brown markings. Mesothorax and metathorax with contrasting brown macula adjacent to dorsal coxal articulation; in some individuals this macula occupies most part of episternum on metathorax and smaller part of episternum on mesothorax; remainder cuticle of thoracic pleura and sterna colorless ( Fig. 102 ). Legs light with or without diffusive darker macula at middle of femur, knee articulation, tibia just distad of patella-tibial suture and/or base of tarsus ( Fig. 102 ). Abdominal terga at most light, with few contrasting brown maculae ( Figs 96 , 100–101 ): tergum I at most brown; tergum II with anterior-median part and pair of submedian myo-sigilla brown; terga III–V at most colorless, tergum VI at most brown, tergum VII with unpaired medio-anterior brown macula, tergum VIII colorless, tergum IX often with lateral parts brown, tergum X light with brownish maculae. Abdominal sterna and paraprocts at most colorless. Caudalii light, often with brown band near apex ( Fig. 92–93 , 100–101 ).

caption.paragraph:
TABLE 4. Leg proportions of male
Cloeodes redactus
measured on outer side of leg.

TABLE 5. Leg proportions of male
C. nigrohumeris
sp. n.
measured on outer side of leg of paratype No. [XXI] (4) 2013.

subSubSection.paragraph:
DEVELOPING MALE GENITALS: In last larval instar, developing subimaginal gonostyli folded under larval cuticle in «
Nigrobaetis
-type» pose, with 2nd segment bent by convexity medially, and 3rd segment directed caudally ( Fig. 116 ).
RESPIRATORY MOVEMENTS: Larva is able to make respiratory vibrations by tergalii.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 92–97.
Cloeodes nigrohumeris
sp. n.
92, immature last instar male larva; 93–96, mature last instar male larva ready to molt to subimago: 93, intact condition; 94, its detached cuticle of pronotum and mesonotum; 95, its extracted abdomen with hypodermal coloration; 96, its detached cuticle of abdomen. 97, middle of posterior margin of abdominal tergum IX. Abbreviations: I–X, abdominal segments I–X.

FIGURES 98–103.
Cloeodes nigrohumeris
sp. n.
98–99, subimaginal exuviae: 98, half of mesonotum; 99, part of meso- and metapleuron with postsubalar sclerite and lateropostnotal crest; 100–103, larval exuviae: 100–101, abdomen and caudalii; 102, left thoracic pleura, legs and half of metanotum; 103, half of pronotum and mesonotum (99, holotype).

FIGURES 104–109.
Cloeodes nigrohumeris
sp. n.
, larva. 104–105, left and right mandibles; 106, labrum (apical setae not shown); 107, paraprocts; 108, labium (left half in ventral view; right half in dorsal view); 109, apex of maxilla (104–106, 108– 109, holotype). Abbreviations: ds1, ds2, ds3, dentisetae.

FIGURES 110–115.
Cloeodes nigrohumeris
sp. n.
110, male imago and its enlarged wing margin; 111, male imago; 112, fore leg of male imago; 113, middle leg of male imago; 114, female imago and its enlarged wing margin; 115, female imago.

FIGURES 116–118.
Cloeodes nigrohumeris
sp. n.
116, subimaginal gonostyli extracted from mature larva; 117, exuviae of subimaginal genitals; 118, genitals of male imago (gonovectes shown by interrupted line; at right half gonovectal and gonostylar muscles shown by interrupted lines; median styligeral muscle shown by interrupted lines, areas of anterior attachment of median paraproctal muscles shown by dotted lines) (117–118, holotype). Abbreviations: 1, 2, 3, segments of gonostylus; m.IX-X, areas of anterior attachment of median paraproctal muscles (i.e., muscles going from sternum IX to common base of paraprocts); m.sg, median sterno-styligeral muscle; usg, unistyliger.

subSubSection.paragraph: HYPODERMAL COLORATION: As in imago.

Tarsal spines of subimago and imago .
Tarsus of fore leg in male and female without apical spines. Tarsus of middle and hind leg of both sexes with 1 apical spine on initial 3rd tarsomere (next after 1st+2nd tarsomere) ( Table 1 ).

Imago, female. COLORATION ( Figs 114–115 ). Head ocher. Thorax ocher; mesonotum without pair of anterolateral dark stripes characteristic for male. Coloration of wing veins as in male, but somewhat darker. Coloration of legs as in male. Abdomen ocher, with contrasting reddish or brown markings arranged as in male.
Egg . Oval, 0.1 mm length. Chorion irregularly crumpled, without relief (as in Figs 145, 146 ).
Dimension. Fore wing length: male 4.0– 4.1 mm ; female 4.2 mm .
Distribution. Peruvian Amazonia.

Comparison. Larva of
Cloeodes nigrohumeris
sp. n.
is similar to
C. spaceki
by long claws, shape of distal dentiseta of maxilla, widened distal segment of labial palp and cuticular coloration of abdomen; judging by the photo of mature larva ready to molt to subimago (
Massariol et al . 2013
: Fig, 7), male subimago and imago of
C. spaceki
has a pair of contrasting dark stripes on mesonotum as in
C. nigrohumeris
sp. n.
Larva of the new species
C. nigrohumeris
sp. n.
differs from
C. spaceki
by constant presence of reddish hypodermal markings on abdomen ( Figs 92–93 ) and by peculiar subapical seta on dorsal side of glossa ( Fig. 108 ). Tergalius IV of
C. spaceki
is figured as rounded apically (
Massariol et al . 2013
: Fig, 42b), while tergalii of
C. nigrohumeris
sp. n.
are pointed ( Fig. 122 ). This difference can be either species-specific, or caused by poor condition of tergalii in the type series of
C. spaceki
(F.F. Salles, personal communication).
